question: Question_01_(b)
statement:
Let $\displaystyle L$ be the line of intersection of the planes
$\displaystyle x+y+z = 6$ and $\displaystyle x-y+2z = 0$

(b) Find parametric equations for the line through the point
$\displaystyle (10,11,13)$ that is perpendicular to the line
$\displaystyle L$ and parallel to the plane $\displaystyle y=z$
sols:
We are searching for a starting point $\displaystyle  p$ and a direction
vector $\displaystyle  v$ for a line $\displaystyle  M=p+\lambda v$.

Since, the point $\displaystyle \begin{pmatrix} 10\\11\\13\end{pmatrix}$
lies on the line, we choose
$\displaystyle  p = \begin{pmatrix}10\\11\\13\end{pmatrix}$

The direction vector $\displaystyle  v$ must be perpendicular to the
direction vector of $\displaystyle L$, such that $\displaystyle M$ and
$\displaystyle  L$ are perpendicular. Hence
$\displaystyle v\circ\begin{pmatrix}-3\\1\\2\end{pmatrix} = -3v_1 + v_2 + 2v_3 = 0$

The direction vector $\displaystyle  v$ must lie in the plane
$\displaystyle y=z$, then the line $\displaystyle M$ is parallel to the
plane. Hence $\displaystyle v_2 = v_3$.

Together, we obtain
$\displaystyle -3v_1 + v_2 + 2v_2 = -3v_1 + 3v_2 = 0\quad\Rightarrow\quad v_1 = v_2$

With $\displaystyle v_1=v_2=v_3$, we choose the vector $\displaystyle v$
to be $\displaystyle v=\begin{pmatrix}1\\1\\1\end{pmatrix}$

and so
$\displaystyle\ \ M = \begin{pmatrix}10\\11\\13\end{pmatrix} + \lambda\begin{pmatrix}1\\1\\1\end{pmatrix}$
hints:
The line in question, lets call it $\displaystyle M$, has a starting
point $\displaystyle  p$ and a direction vector $\displaystyle  v$, such
that $\displaystyle M = p +\lambda v$.

In the problem formulation, the point $\displaystyle  p$ is already
given.

What does it mean for $\displaystyle M$ to be perpendicular to the line
$\displaystyle  L$? What does it mean for $\displaystyle  M$ to be
parallel to a plane $\displaystyle  y=z$?
